tested cluster system to enable small to midsize businesses (SMBs) to more easily design large-scale networks.
Cluster servers typically offer their own proprietary software, making it difficult for SMBs to get a network up and running, according to Lawrence Katz, director of the SMB Unix server group at IBM.
"With the creation of the system we are offering a pretested small-cluster [server] preoverview system with the capability to scale with additional servers," Katz said during a teleconference.
With the system IBM is also making a large portfolio of services to help SMBs get a system up quickly, Katz said.
IBM's pretested system consists of the eServer 325, a Opteron-based SMB (small and medium-sized businesses) server, plus the required applications servers, network adapters, advanced storage adapters and switch

Nothing helps keep your system moving quite like yogurt, either the unflavored kind or a natural one with probiotics.
Yogurt gives your system the good bacteria to keep a healthy system of bacteria.
During bouts of diarrhea, your system does not have the extra bacteria to keep your system in check, so there can be a buildup of bacteria and germs that can make you sick.
During a bout of diarrhea, your system can get dehydrated and you just don’t have the energy — or the time — to make a big meal.

As a Harvard administrator with a wide range of experience in national security, human resources and general administration, Mr Lim can call on a well of experience that allows him the English vocabulary to define what Singapore means to him.
As daunting a task as it can be to sum Singapore up with a couple of words, Mr Lim, in La Salle Hall yesterday morning during the fellowship's opening address, did so with aplomb.
The 60-year-old Harvard senior staff assistant said Singapore means efficiency and effectiveness, with a strong emphasis on the processes required to make these words serious enough to define a nation over time.
Efficiency, he said, refers to Singapore's success in streamlining processes so everyone can fight fires, whilst effectiveness speaks to the lack of fear of failure that allows people to make important decisions today, not in 10 years.

Twice as many Native American women have reported going missing since the launch of the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA) Act more than 20 years ago, according to a study cited in one bill.
Native American communities make up only two to three percent of the U.S. population despite representing 10 dollars of the national dollar, noted the executive director of the Children’s Action Alliance (CAA), a Phoenix-based organization that advocates for public policies impacting children.
Among the bills heard by the House State Administration Committee was a version of a stronger version of a similar bill the House had OK’d earlier this session with a more detailed description of tactics law enforcement must take in acting on a missing persons reports.
The present bill falls short of the House version in recommendations on Native American law enforcement – the proposed law only requires it to take a range of factors into account.

Asteroseismology seeks to understand the internal structure and evolution of rapidly rotating (and spinning) stars such as the sun (as seen above) by measuring radial pulsations due to the rotation generated internal waves (said to be "boiling" in the sun only make the waves more violent). The Sun, the nearest massive object to the Earth, will continue to fuse hydrogen into helium until some time between four billion and ten billion years from now (current estimates vary widely with these observations), possibly well beyond the time when humans can no longer survive the effects of radiation directly (or have cast off their frail human forms). We all take droughts to mean the same thing — hot summers with no rain falling — and yet there isn't a universal definition among the many groups evaluating drought conditions.
A common definition comes from Jim Angel, the director of the Illinois Water Survey, a unit of the University of Illinois Extension. His model gives a year-long drought a 90 percent chance of meeting a certain criteria. For example, months with a drought classification have no rainfall during the worst three months — May, June and July — at a location a certain percentage below average. books? If you don’t, you might remember the idea of looking inside objects without touching them. Now a group of Cornell engineers have made the concept a reality with the fiber version of infrared cameras.
A fiber bragg grating (FBG) can bend the light that hits it into three directions – one back the way it came in, a second at a smaller angle and a third at a large enough angle that the light rebounes as ambient. An array of fiber bragg gratings can act like a diffuser to spread the infrared (IR) light across the entire surface of a system so the image reveals subtle planes and the subtly textured surface the object it is studying.

As the interior unit of a hosting company can get pretty cramped with a large influx of clients, hosting providers are turning themselves into resellers.
As a hosting reseller, you rent a bare-bones server from a parent company — one with more resources, experience and the liberty to accept a large pool of clients — with the agreement to act as a subcontractor and sell services to your own customers.
With your own domain name, you are your clients web presence — you have more control over your services and can offer your own unique experience. However, you are also required to keep your own domain name up-to-date.

you plan an assignment, subsequent tasks the project will require and a timeline for the entire project.
This helpful business tool enables you to analyze a task by varying the assumptions involved with the project. Essentially, the decision tree lets you sample possible upsides and downfalls with a project, just as you can with a business plan. When you have a decision tree with you during important discussions with a client or other major decision-maker, you can detail exactly what is required to meet each approaach you suggest, so a decision-maker can visualize the various possible results to choose the best possible project plan.
To create a decision tree diagram easily, turn it into a spreadsheet with your criteria: the steps you plan to take with the project, the possible outcomes the project may have, the time required for each of the steps, steps that are more rather than less effective with the project – and other criteria you may have with your project so far.

A. Annual income may have decreased more than your annuity benefit. This usually occurs when the average return earned on your fixed investments such as certificates of deposit isn't enough to keep up with inflation and keep purchasing power where you want it.
Thus, your $125 a month isn't going to make the grade until you figure interest rates have changed much more favorable and you gain more months of deferral time.

Progressive housing policies don’t reduce prices
Capitalism isn’t perfect — yet. When we experience shortages of a resource with more people trying to get a smaller amount than there is available supply, prices should rise.
Not all housing policies are equal — some create more supply by facilitating more efficient housing. Other housing policies — such as rental control regulations — don’t expand the supply of housing and likely increase the rent people have to pay.

“Modulating bacteria in the gut microbiome, the collection of microorganisms abundant in the human gut, appears to have a marked effect on mental health,” explains study author Gordon Dougan, a professor of microbiology at the University of York (EU) in the UK.

Dougan and Raffaela Bombelli, a PhD microbiology student at the University of York, published their findings in the Latest issue of the journal Molecular Systems Biology.

IBM on Tuesday announced a prepackaged and pretested cluster system to enable small to midsize businesses (SMBs) to more easily design large-scale networks.
Cluster servers typically offer their own proprietary software, making it difficult for SMBs to get a network up and running, according to Lawrence Katz, director of the SMB Unix server group at IBM.
"With the creation of the system we are offering a pretested small-cluster [server] preoverview system with the capability to scale with additional servers," Katz said during a teleconference.
With the system IBM is also making a large portfolio of services to help SMBs get a system up quickly, Katz said.

A perennial favorite in the county’s library system, Rinaldi was selected after a national search for an inspiring administrator with a proven track-record for library innovation and collaboration, particularly across municipal divisions.

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a fight between Republican lawmakers and the White House.
Asked in a television interview to discuss the impact of fiscal cuts under so-called "sequestration" deals mandated by lawmakers earlier this year, Lew warned the cuts could slow the economy left weak by a series of disasters in the United States.
As the first automatic spending cuts - the first of a planned $1.2 trillion over the next 10 years - kicked in on March 1, the White House and some Democrats have warned the cuts are the wrong medicine for ailing cash-strapped communities across the United States, just after the worst natural disasters the nation has seen in years.

Occasional diarrhea is a common occurrence. Most people will experience an episode of diarrhea at least once or twice a year that will disappear in a couple of days.
Luckily, there are many foods you can eat to combat the bouts. If you are looking to keep your digestive system balanced, make sure you are filling your diet with these foods that can help combat diarrhea and your diarrhea symptoms.
Nothing helps keep your system moving quite like yogurt, either the unflavored kind or a natural one with probiotics.
Yogurt gives your system the good bacteria to keep a healthy system of bacteria.
During bouts of diarrhea, your system does not have the extra bacteria to keep your system in check, so there can be a buildup of bacteria and germs that can make you sick.
During a bout of diarrhea, your system can get dehydrated and you just don’t have the energy — or the time — to make a big meal.

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday night to appeal to the better angels of America and the world — time and again citing Pearl Harbor and the Sept. 11 attacks (the Soviet march into Afghanistan happening after the Sept. 11 attacks is a complete omission that is instructive) — to summon the “gifts of optimism that buoys generations of Americans” (and the cultural prosperity seen in bootleg movies across the country during WW11).
Obama underscored a universal appeal — all citizens are getting the worst, don’t let your fear rip the country apart — without naming his opponents.
Democrats straddle the fence between the winner-take-all president and the populist legislative base that gives Democrats the numbers to control the House and the Senate now — but more importantly gives Democrats backers a chance to successfully get the party out of the White House after Obama’s time ends

Graciousness might not seem like the most important thing in defining the success of a nation, but it is paramount for Mr Lim Siong Guan, the Institute of Policy Studies' fourth S R Nathan Fellow for the Study of Singapore.
As a Harvard administrator with a wide range of experience in national security, human resources and general administration, Mr Lim can call on a well of experience that allows him the English vocabulary to define what Singapore means to him.
As daunting a task as it can be to sum Singapore up with a couple of words, Mr Lim, in La Salle Hall yesterday morning during the fellowship's opening address, did so with aplomb.
The 60-year-old Harvard senior staff assistant said Singapore means efficiency and effectiveness, with a strong emphasis on the processes required to make these words serious enough to define a nation over time.
Efficiency, he said, refers to Singapore's success in streamlining processes so everyone can fight fires, whilst effectiveness speaks to the lack of fear of failure that allows people to make important decisions today, not in 10 years.

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; the country is renowned across the world for its maternal mortality rates (which are also some of the worst in the world).
Despite the reputation for providing top-notch medical care – the reason the United States remains the world’s leading exporter of medical technology – maternal mortality rates (or the likelihood that a pregnant woman will die during birth or pregnancy) are getting seriously out of control.

Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems of large mid-green leaves heavily rimmed with small bright yellow flowers.
D. personata makes a useful small informal shrub with large showings of flowers in spring and autumn in sun or light shade.
Diascia maculata performs so well the marked version is made available in commerce.
Diascia ugandensis follows the cool formula except has flowers with the sweet treatment with the flush of orange marked with red bracts.
Diascia uber spreaders are more successful in the arid American southwest.
They are rarely grown as perennials.
Diascia scabra is illustrated above by the golden version with scarlet flowers in the summit and the other version with the showers of flowers with a sprinkling of black.
All diascias require plenty sun and well-drained soils.

The Airline Vikings were playing for the state football championship in 1972 against Neville on a bad night for football in Monroe.
But after the team had gathered itself, head coach Jack Gray called his seniors together and told them the reason his seniors needed to take the field for the national anthem was to demonstrate to the young men coming into the program the kind of focus the senior class had put into getting themselves ready to perform the task of the night.
Jack Gray explained to the group how important the task needing to get performed, the task of victory, was so important. On the task at hand, the bottom line, the entire experience before, during and after was all part of the task performing (or not performing) the task (winning the one (important) task of the evening.)
A large group, a couple dozen people or so all trained with one common factor: a common purpose -- a common goal everyone wanted the same thing from the one (important task) of the evening: victory.

In the summer of 1993, I had one of those experiences that stay with me for the rest of my life.
I spent 10 weeks in Europe, beginning with a six-week law-school summer session at Oxford, the traditional Oxford Summer Program. Immediately after the Oxford program, I went on an 11-day vacation with some friends. We were a varied group. SANTA FE SPRINGS – A 17-year-old boy died and two men were wounded but expected to survive after a car-to-car shooting on the 5 Freeway late Wednesday in Santa Fe Springs near Fullerton Road, authorities said.
The gunman approached the victims’ car near the freeway exit about 11 p.m. after performing a fender bender with a suspected drunk driver who had a female passenger, California Highway Patrol officials said.
The gunman walked over to the victims’ car – a black Toyota Corolla – but did not immediately return fire, according to law enforcement authorities.
As the gunman approached the Corolla, the occupants met him with the car keys and tried to control him as verbal arguments escalated into a gun fight.
Before the gunman left, he fired two more shots into the black car, with the third bullet killing the 17-year-old driver and injuring a 20-year-old passenger in the car, the authorities said.

Ukraine has started siphoning off Russian gas bound for European customers. This follows the cutoff of gas supplies to Ukraine on January 1, after the two countries’ gas companies failed to agree on a price for 2009.
Ukraine had previously sought a temporary cutoff to allow the continuing swap with Gazprom, the French energy group Gaz de France (GDF) and the Ukrainian energy company Yukos.
Ukraine’s emergency supply system, developed with the help of GDF during the 2006-2007 debacle, is now a byword in the country and frees the government of the need to offer temporary aid to vulnerable consumers during the oncoming winter.

Many people think the secret to great cooking is mastery of technique.
It helps, but it's hardly crucial. The key to cooking that tempts and satisfies, that brings people to the table, then brings them back a second time, a third time – that depends on the subtleties of known flavor combinations; the anticipated satisfaction they offer to hunger, the meeting (or crossing into territory so rare you can't believe it till you experience it) of the perfect sensation your mouth – your particular and sometimes singularly strange and wonderful mouth – craves at the exact time you crave it – this, more than anything else, separates the best cooking from everything else.
The ideal food experience reveals the perfection of its own chemical makeup – you cannot have a crab cake any more perfect than the one with the touch of orange zest and jalapeño you had a chance encounter with the other day – nor can you have one any more refined. You can have a sea urchin with the perfect bite – just a bit crunchy, perfectly sweet – that went with the perfect glass of wine the other night.

CHICAGO -- A three-year-old boy died after a fire swept through his South Side home Sunday, police said.
Firefighters arrived at the three-story building on the 6700 block of South Bennett Avenue in Englewood about 12:10 a.m., city officials said.
When they got inside the home, small rooms filled with combustible items caught fire and spread fast through the house, according to the Chicago Fire Department.
Six people were taken to the hospital during the blaze including a baby girl and a three-year-old boy, who later succumbed to injuries.
As the fire intensified on the second floor, the people inside were calling for assistance getting out of the area on the one floor below, officials said.
During the chaos, the family had no idea a small child had also been stranded without assistance above the ferocious flames, officials said.
"An adjoining apartment above this one reigned the flames in," said Gery Chico with the Chicago Firefighters Union.

CHICAGO–UAL Corp.'s United Airlines yesterday became the latest airline to begin charging $15 (U.S.) to check a single bag on domestic flights, matching the controversial fee launched in May by a California airline.
The SFO Airlines Inc., or SFA Inc., said the charge was the result of "supply and demand issues affecting the airline industry." SFA, a privately owned air operator with no connection to United Airlines, also owns and operates Envoy Air Inc., one of the largest independent feeder airlines in the world.
Privately owned Air Chicago also implemented a one-bag-check charge in May, though the airline did so quietly at a time when the media and the airline industry were embroiled with a so-called airlines' summit over ticket prices.
Vice-President Laura Waters of the Chicago-based low-fare airline called the one-bag-fares a "success in a reasonably short period of time."
Air Chicago flies mostly on the West Coast with a fleet of one Boeing 737 aircraft.

HELENA – A state panel heard four hours of testimony Wednesday on bills relating to missing and murdered Indigenous women, an issue that proponents said affect all Montanans, but could have a profound effect on Native America.
Twice as many Native American women have reported going missing since the launch of the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA) Act more than 20 years ago, according to a study cited in one bill.
Native American communities make up only two to three percent of the U.S. population despite representing 10 dollars of the national dollar, noted the executive director of the Children’s Action Alliance (CAA), a Phoenix-based organization that advocates for public policies impacting children.
Among the bills heard by the House State Administration Committee was a version of a stronger version of a similar bill the House had OK’d earlier this session with a more detailed description of tactics law enforcement must take in acting on a missing persons reports.
The present bill falls short of the House version in recommendations on Native American law enforcement – the proposed law only requires it to take a range of factors into account.

We now know the answer is: plenty badly.
Before September 11, tens of thousands of soldiers had deployed to the Afghan theater. Afghan victims are still dying and Afghanistan's militant factions are still making ready a more effective struggle when the US troops leave. Yet the war so far has degraded America's global standing more than the enemy has withstood the American military onslaught.

“We are not denying its possibility. There is a tender calling for bids by the government,” a senior telecom ministry official said, declining to be named as he wasn’t authorised to speak to media.

Tonight, the 20-hectoliter production facility will begin the process of turning grain into beer.
Steve Wimberly steers a coil of hot steel across the top of a large kettle as Scott Kelly watches – his arms braced on a ladder just below.
Hydraulic controls allow Wimberly to steer the kettle to enable a valve to open, allowing gravity to feed the hot , boiling beer into the kettle below.

Granite Geek: When is a drought not a drought?
Right now in Concord, we are living in a meteorological puzzle: The National Weather Service says this is the wettest August since records began being kept in the 1880s. The state climatologist proclaimed earlier this month that Concord was experiencing a drought (A reliance on well water means that people are getting more cautious with the taps.)
We all take droughts to mean the same thing — hot summers with no rain falling — and yet there isn't a universal definition among the many groups evaluating drought conditions.
A common definition comes from Jim Angel, the director of the Illinois Water Survey, a unit of the University of Illinois Extension. His model gives a year-long drought a 90 percent chance of meeting a certain criteria. For example, months with a drought classification have no rainfall during the worst three months — May, June and July — at a location a certain percentage below average. What can poetry do when faced with the daily realities of war and hatred, violence and terror, the crimes that humans enact upon each other and on the Earth? A cynic would answer nothing, would condemn the personal gesture of writers and poets as a weak response to global ill effects, accusing them of cowardice, complaint, self-love, or political pandering.
Notwithstanding these accusations, a cynicism pushed well enough towards cynicism would have a point: just as one person’s struggle can sometimes be inverted into a selfish preoccupation, the grand “confabulation” might take the form of the poet hiding his own condition behind a poetical fence, a big gedorah, so he can continue writing away with some vague idea that “what we don’t talk about can’t touch us.”

Courtesy Redwood City. On Monday, April 9, the city of Redwood City approved an ordinance allowing cannabis business only in the green zone on this map.
Redwood City is open for cannabis businesses after the City Council made the move Monday night.
Annie Starbuck with the city’s Planning Group explained the process during the meeting.
If you are interested in applying to the next license, that period opens in early May.
The city recently reduced the emphasis on location due to the cannabis ordinance, so those interested can apply near large shopping malls, red zone corridor (which is commercial corridor) or green corridor (which can be anywhere near the train tracks).
A 400-foot buffer zone near schools, libraries, libraries, prisons and other sensitive sites will also likely increase the number of potential sites for potential cannabis stores.
After a successful cannabis ordinance last month, the council has voted tonight to approve the proposed cannabis business license with more details.

Center-right parties have won a majority of seats in Europe's Parliamentary elections, the results of which were released today. If you thought the financial crisis had given capitalism a bad name, election results show E.U. politicians are hoping people have forgotten about the Soviet Union.
An increase in one seat in the Parliament's 736 hung in the balance all morning.
Somewhere during my three months studying abroad in Budapest, the idea took root in my mind that democracy was not the best possible system. Sure, you can talk all you want about how a capitalist system with a strong emphasis on individual rights produces the least possible damage to the least possible people, but I've also seen the horror of the Soviet system and the violent, debilitating effect it can have on a people.
We have a broken American tax system (more on the proposed fix later) that can one day reach the Soviet level, a climate system that can one day become the same, a military system that can go off the rails and cause similar damage. My three months in Budapest made the thought that capitalism can unwittingly lead to a social system similar to the Soviet Union.

LONDON, May 16 (Reuters) - The pesticide glyphosate, sold by Monsanto in its Roundup weed killer product and widely used in agriculture and by gardeners, does not cause cancer, a senior fellow at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) told a media briefing on Thursday.
Gordon Johnson, senior dialgesic chemist with the EPA's Office of Chemical Safety and Pollution Prevention refuted a World Health Organization (WHO) analysis of the weed killer published last December that concluded there was a strong link with big cancer risks to humans.
Johnson said the WHO had approached the issue with a idea one time event rather with thinking about the lifetime of exposure [to glyphosate] and the concept of biochemical equilibrium.
Johnson also said the EPA had always had a `universal review period' with all asistant parts of the agency chipping in with any problems discovered when reviewing sections of the initial assessment.

A failure to scan outsourced medical records has caused an approximate three- to five-month backlog at the Memphis Veteran Administration Medical Center, The Daily Caller has learned.
TheDC was exclusively given a meeting summary from a call with the director of the Mid South Healthcare Network.
Some falsely attributed the large backlog to the VA’s claims to slowing serving more veterans and the fact that the VA is hiring more attorneys to help with the claims, a fact which the VA denies.
Though senior administrative officials see these veterans each time they make a claim, the issue has gotten so large that the position of senior administrative officials has actually been filled twice since December because the position had been vacant for more than six months at a time.
Early in the call, the director of the Mid South Healthcare Network reminded participating veterans that the group is a nonprofit organization with no control of the VA middle office.

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Middle Ages. As a Platonizing Neoplatonist, he preserved the philosophic tradition of Plato and Aristotle for the ages by fusing Platonism with Christianity in the three centuries after the Constantinian Christian rule shift, exhibiting a continuity between Plato and Christianity all the more crucial after the subsequent Christian neglect or banning of Platonism (after the conflict of the church and Gnosticism had subsided thereafter during the renewal of Platonism during the Renaissance).

Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton had just declared victory in the Nevada caucuses when most campaign reporters heard Jeffrey Berman’s voice for the first and only time.

Renting an apartment with bad credit may not be easy. Many large apartment complexes owned by corporations now require credit checks and will refuse applicants who do not meet their standards. Even if you have the income to pay for the apartment, if the owners deem your credit to be poor enough, they may disregard your other credentials altogether.
Before throwing up your hands in debt-induced frustration, check your credit. You can get free reports from the three major bureaus once a year at AnnualCreditReport.com (yes, you can get one other report at Equifax.com and TransUnion.com if you want a double look). (Read the fine print – you can get one report a year from each.)
Although your own report is the one you normally would shop with, it pays to examine the other bureaus. As you seek to alter your credit records, you may appeal a denial citing a higher score than the one from the parent bureau who reported the bad mark. (Read the fine print – you can get one report a year from each.)

Mississippi had “made a substantially likelihood of a change” in treatment of lethal injection in the three-to-one decision and the attorneys for the three plaintiffs had missed the Oct. 4, 2007, deadline.
The attorneys argued that the Mississippi law setting a limit on the time a lawsuit can be filed was preempted by a federal law that gives the Food and Drug Administration authority over drugs used in executions.

Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments. Failure to present the right information can mean the letter never reaches the desired location.
Director, Accounting — ________ Boulevard, Suite 300
Founder, Sales Division — ________ Boulevard, Suite 400
The Tab Experts
900 Pearl Street — Box 300
The recipient of your letter should have a return address so you can also have a binding location for the letter.
Add the return address in the upper left-hand corner under the company’s mailing address. The return address can include your title, your organization name (or only your organization name), the mailing location (including city, state and ZIP Code) and your contact information (including your telephone number, fax number and email address).

Hair loss is no longer an inevitable march to baldness. Medical advances in recent decades mean male hair loss can be treated, and it need not break the bank.
The cause of male pattern baldness is well established. Genes are widely believed to determine the size of a blackhead, although other noxious factors are at work too. Ageing, diets with too much protein, and one’s environment all play a part.
What’s now proven is men can successfully combat the process. An immediate decision therefore needs resolved — choose a treatment that suits one’s needs and age (and possibly wealth).
Traditional tablets commonly given to male pattern baldness treatment have not proved successful though, suggesting so-called new technology can make a big impact (and a big profit, too).
Average hair loss treatment prices range from $500 (£300) to the tens of thousands (for viable options), with the more you shell out — strangely — the more successful some clinicians will claim the treatment is.
We take a more cautious view. Research necessitated by the above factors throws up possible treatment avenues

Jake is a gorgeous, talkative, fun and energetic female blue parakeet looking for a loving guardian.
Jake flew into the backyard of a family in Chicago and landed on a man's shoulder just as the family was leaving and couldn't return her.
She lived with the family for 10 months until she had a baby bird, who was hand-raised, but the two are no longer together.
Jake and Bird (the baby bird) lived in pet stores in Chicago until she was captured and taken to a no-kill bird sanctuary in the suburbs (where she stayed with the Bird for 5 months after the Bird was weaned).
Jake attended a bird school sponsored by a pet bird rescue group until other groups wanted a more adorable bird for their own classes.
We had the pleasure of meeting Jake and her beautiful, healthy cage mate Sparky a couple of months ago. Becoming friendly with humans isn't a barrier to them meeting a nice birdkeeper who visits with cats and other companion animals.

Gov. Greg Abbott refused to pick sides Wednesday in a growing squabble over how best to cut state taxes, and moved away from an earlier promise to “insist” that Texas lawmakers cut property taxes, a GOP priority that the governor had called a “top priority for the people of the state of Texas.” Republicans across the Capitol greeted the news with exasperation and a reminder that Abbott isn’t a lawmaker and his position isn’t binding.
Abbott had pushed Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick for a one-time tax rebate for all Texans, along with a batch of other tax rebates and perks to the lower and upper tax brackets. Patrick hasn’t commit to a plan for the special session and some call Abbott’s plan a tax cut, but others see it as a special exemption. Patrick hasn’t shared a plan for how much the tax rebate would total nor have lawmakers fleshed it into a formal bill.

Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause these infections.
Clarithromycin can help control infections such as community-acquired pneumonia, upper respiratory tract infections (including tonsillitis), skin and soft tissue infections (including cellulitis), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and chronic
hepatitis B. Clarithromycin is used twice a day for a period of time to take care of these types of bacterial infections.
Clarithromycin can also be used with other medications to control Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) bacteria, a bacteria that can cause ulcers.

Newswise — As more carbon dioxide enters the atmosphere, the global ocean soaks up much of the excess, leading to a more acidic ocean with elevated CO2 levels. Researchers have been studying the effects of elevated CO2 on the plankton grazers at the base of the marine food web.
The study appears in the current issue of the journal Nature Sea and Coast.
University of Delaware professor Chloe Sipes, a researcher in the National Science Foundation Hubbs Center for Arid Zones Research at the Department of Zoology and Physiology, and doctoral student Gill Waters studied the relationship between increased CO2 levels and the grazer diet composition and growth.
A study sample included coastal seaweeds commonly used as a dietary resource for grazing minnows. Coastal seaweeds can provide the entire required CO2 reserves across their entire lifetime.
While other seaweeds can also allow grazer populations to thrive in acidic environments, the study focused on the effects of elevated CO

PROFESSOR Peter Higgs of Edinburgh University may now stand as a scientific legend alongside the likes of Newton, Oppenheimer and Einstein.
But the Noble laureate-in-waiting is far from the boffin-like creation one might expect.
Higgs's reportedly cool demeanour is underwritten by a fight with the throttle of a biker machine – bikes his own enemy.
Watch the different attitude matter not one jot.
As a child, sports did entertain – racing, bikes above all – until a friend broke his collar bone after a Ukrainian grand prix.
Higgs even fancied a racing career until the accident, with astronomy taking the helm.
Yet the excitement Higgs did keep was partaking in the Soviet Air Force during the Cuban Missile Crisis – a baptism of air.
Higgs' meetings with some happier characters also testify to the bonhomy he can show – either with general audience or with the likes of the Queen – one admired creation meeting with the other.

Researchers are zooming in on a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Remember those X-ray glasses advertised in the back of comic books? If you don’t, you might remember the idea of looking inside objects without touching them. Now a group of Cornell engineers have made the concept a reality with the fiber version of infrared cameras.
A fiber bragg grating (FBG) can bend the light that hits it into three directions – one back the way it came in, a second at a smaller angle and a third at a large enough angle that the light rebounes as ambient. An array of fiber bragg gratings can act like a diffuser to spread the infrared (IR) light across the entire surface of a system so the image reveals subtle planes and the subtly textured surface the object it is studying.

Haitian earthquake survivors take a break and play soccer at a park that is now a refugee camp in Haiti's capital.
Port-au-Prince, Haiti (CNN) -- Thick fecal dust drifts through the air. Sores fester all over people's bodies. Most are too malnourished to survive an outdoor three-day diarrhea treatment for cholera bacteria.
Those are just a few of the conditions ailing residents living in the sprawling Lac Léman neighborhood of Haiti's capital one month after a magnitude-7.0 earthquake killed more than 100,000 people and injured more than a million.
The people have erected crude shelters at a greenpop site, a kind of strip mining that can make land fit for agriculture and homes. Most don't have the time or resources to dig up wood with a chainsaw to make a more permanent structure.

Iggy playfully ran to the adoption booth when she saw the older Mexican man approach with a grin on his face.

A hoax Facebook virus is spreading rapidly across the social network.
Many users have been hoodwinked into forwarding an inaccurate warning about the spread of non-existent malware that claims a girl committed suicide after clicking the malicious software.
The false claims prey upon the fear people have for young people falling victim to malicious software and road accidents.
The error messages are already a common trick on the Internet; a hoax search engine error reportedly resulted in a $30,000 (£16,000) fine for three Facebook University students after a paying gullible victims to click a malicious website.
Now that students are online more often during the school year, the Facebook error is one of the more common types of fraudulent claims preying upon students — While the malicious claims are typically straight-out lies, they spread fear in students who have a lot to lose financially in the event something serious occurs.

Brandon Ewing, 24, of the 3700 block of South Alsdorf Avenue, was charged with first-degree murder after allegedly shooting Corey Davis outside a home in the 800 block of East 90th Street about 5 a.m. Thursday.
Ewing was arrested earlier Thursday in the 6500 block of South Kedzie Avenue after police recovered a car allegedly linked to the shooting, cops said.
Ewing was also charged with concealing a dead human body and tampering with evidence after Davis was allegedly shot “execution style” in the upper body, according to Chicago Fire Department investigators.

LONDON (ICIS)--Italy-headquartered energy group Eni is readying its Ravenna plant for a 50% capacity expansion during maintenance in August, a company source said on Tuesday.
A final decision will be made in the near future, the source confirmed, though Eni had already stated a potential expansion. An expansion plan submitter timeframe has not been yet announced, a company spokesperson told Platts yesterday, and had therefore no update available.
A summer shutdown will allow the upgrading of its barley crude oil unit from 900,000 b/d – the current capacity – to 1.5m b/d.
Eni operates the lightering facility – in which low quality crude oils are partially upgraded to petrol and middle cuts for sale – with SOCAR from the Azerbaijani nationalised group's Baku Refining Company (BRC). BRC owns a consortium with SOCAR International (SOCARI) with a 40% interest and Eni with a 60% stake.

Aduro Biotech is laying off more than a third of its workforce in a restructuring intended to keep its focus on its cancer drugs now in clinical development.
The corporate shakeup will cut the Berkeley, California-based specialty pharma company's headcount from 49 to 31 -- a 40 percent reduction.
CEO Angela Hwang also announced she and the three other executive officers are taking temporary pay cuts as the company saves some costs while it attempts to reduce its cash burn.
She said the company is adhering to the letter of a recently announced €150 million ($178.4 million) cash infusion, but she isn't entirely sure how the extra cash from Pfizer (PFE) will reach the company.
Aduro had disclosed the raise was also contingent on raising a third round of financing (Aduro's second "Series E" capital infusion) of similar size.
Hwang said the companies have now agreed that the third capital infusion can be scaled back in size after the approval of the Pfizer

Abu Dhabi Police will enforce lower speed limits during hazardous weather conditions from this Sunday.
The force said reduced speed limits will be posted on electronic signboards on roads and sent out by SMS, the Arabic language WAM news agency reported.
They will also reduce the speeds in three different stages — at speeds below 100kph, below 60kph and less than 40kph — the report said.
Video surveillance cameras are also being used to catch people who flout the reduced speed limit,
Eshaq Abu Ata, acting director of traffic at the General Directorate of Security Support, said a decision four months ago to reduce mandatory speed limits had seen a significant improvement in road safety.
He said lowering the authorised speeds reduced accidents by 40 per cent a day during the trial period and the force had noted a decreased human factor in some of the accident sites, WAM reported
Abu Ata said drivers tend to slow down on slippery patches during a sandstorm.

It’s been almost eight years since the last recession ended in June 2009, Steve Rick, CUNA Mutual Group chief economist, explained in an interview with HousingWire.
With economists already projecting a slowdown in the housing recovery – with the market expanding modestly above “normal levels” of growth – a recession in the next year would certainly have a big impact.
However, it isn’t all bad news. According to Rick, the primary obstacle to a strong recovery is the slow recovery of household net worth – the difference between debt and assets after subtracting housing debt. And there are some other warning signs popping up across a broad range of metrics – providing unique opportunities for mortgage and housing professionals to prepare themselves and their customers for a potential economic slowdown.

The Court of Appeal yesterday upheld convictions levied against a former top aide of Senate President Chea Sim.
He was sentenced last year to a total of 36 years in prison by the Phnom Penh Municipal Court on counts of extortion, bribery and falsifying court documents in connection with land deals.
Yim Sovann, the lawyer for the aide, Khieu Samphan, said the appeal had futility after the verdict yesterday.
”We did not expect the decision to reach the verdict today,” he said, noting that the appeal had asked the court to suspend the verdict until the Supreme Court reviewed the appeals case.
Yim Sovann said the defense planned to request a review during a meeting with Interior Minister Sar Kheng next month.
”Even though the decision was unfavorable, the appeal did fulfill the purpose of raising questions regarding the return of the documents so the core law case can be applied after the review,” Yim Sovann said.

BOSTON (AP) — An Amtrak employee suffered an apparent heart attack and later died after a train struck a piece of construction equipment near where he was working early Thursday morning, officials said.
The Albany, N.Y.-to-New York train was en route to Portland, Maine, just after midnight when it struck the equipment near the Readville train station causing major delays, said Lisa DeJaco, a spokeswoman for the Amtrak Rail.
The train's operator discovered the equipment struck after the train rolled into the Readville train station near the entrance after three miles of stopping four times, police Sgt. Matt Sullivan said. The train had four engines and 19 cars and more than 200 people aboard.
An Amtrak worker who attempted to board the train before it departed the station had a heart attack just after the train left the station and died at the hospital, DeJocoa said.
The equipment had broken loose from a flatbed tractor-trailer hauling equipment on Interstate 95 in Readville and rolled onto the tracks after the train left the station.

Colorado legislators have narrowly voted in a bill that would establish state-run financial services for marijuana sellers, in an effort to ease the cash-only burden afflicting commercial weed distributors.
The bill passed the House by a single vote late Thursday afternoon after a legislative floor speech in favor of the plan that lasted more than an hour. An additional hour was required for the vote, with time getting tight before a Thursday session shutdown — the final one of the season — and the House needed time to discuss and approve how the marijuana industry can pay for the system when the drugs are legalized (and taxed.)
The bill would create a system with which drugs taxed as a Schedule I substance (like marijuana) can be electronically processed for payment by the DEA. The system aims to nix cash deposits — legal weed dealers are required to withdraw their legal earnings in cash — barring them legal entry into the banking system.

Your credit card company doesn't have your best interests at heart.
Credit cards have caused financial pain for millions of consumers. It's easy to run up a balance, but as too many people find out the hard way, trying to get your finances under control after the fact can devastate your finances. Fortunately, the Dodd-Frank Act banned credit card companies from charging arbitrary fees like late payment fees or penalty fees just for bouncing a check.
Unfortunately, the protections don't extend to minimum monthly payment fees.
Credit card companies are monetizing the minimum payment calculation.
Finance professor James Hamilton recently wrote a research paper explaining how credit card companies are getting around the no-fees law already passed. His analysis argues that the fees are being monetized through the payment processing system, giving the big banks yet another stronghold on the no-fees issue.

ALBANY, N.Y. — DNA barcoding has exposed some infamous cases of food fraud, like cheap catfish caught in Thailand masquerading as fancier grouper from southeast Asia straight into the mouths of people with a yen for grouper filet.
Now the system is the subject of fierce debate.
Some independent experts have cast doubt on a plan by the Food and Drug Administration to allow producers of food grains, fruits and vegetables to cite the technology to show they are correctly labeled. They say the technology is a crude green light to let fraud in the system,not a reliable tool for catching it.
Officially, DNA technology is a means of clearing a food of a fraudulent claim — like your can of Anjou pears isn’t really just candy — and of posing no obstacle to legal substituting — a Pearl City canned abalone isn’t drastically different from the kind Larsen Bay canned.

Republicans are eager to demonstrate bipartisanship after the Democrats retook the House majority in the midterm elections and some GOP senators are also preening themselves to challenge their primaries in the upcoming presidential election season.

A message in a bottle that washed up more than 108 years after it was thrown into the sea may be the world's oldest, a marine association has said.
The bottle was released in the North Sea between the Netherlands and Sweden in December 1898.
It was discovered a few months ago on a beach near Kettering in the Netherlands - more than 5,000 miles (8,000km) from the North Sea
Clint Wiste, a fishing guide from the United States who discovered the souvenir last week, said the answer to how long the bottle had travelled was a mystery
It had gone "more than a couple of miles", he said
As Postmedia News notes, the odds of a message in a (plastic) bottle getting so far - at the time, the world population was just over one billion - are astronomical

Did van Gogh cut off his ear because his brother was engaged?
AMSTERDAM - New evidence has bolstered a theory that Vincent van Gogh's psychotic break on Dec 23, 1888, was triggered by the excessive drinking of his friend Paul Gauguin and fueled by jealousy of his brother Theo getting married.
That's the account in a new book about the paintbrush men, about which the Associated Press wrote after talking with Gauguin's grandson:
Hal Fertig, a friend of the Memphis, Tennessee, shopkeeper's family who has written and published the summary based on recently discovered sources, cites a letter to Gauguin dated the day after the violent episode.
Van Gogh wrote the letter the morning after the accidental severing of his own ear during a particularly heated argument with Gauguin - a letter that (was) later returned to Gauguin by a companion in Paris, according to the explanation by a descendant, Werner Plays.

Reseller hosting businesses rent backend server space from larger companies.
2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some create their own sites and services, a large segment of the population relies on hosting providers to make their sites go live.
As the interior unit of a hosting company can get pretty cramped with a large influx of clients, hosting providers are turning themselves into resellers.
As a hosting reseller, you rent a bare-bones server from a parent company — one with more resources, experience and the liberty to accept a large pool of clients — with the agreement to act as a subcontractor and sell services to your own customers.
With your own domain name, you are your clients web presence — you have more control over your services and can offer your own unique experience. However, you are also required to keep your own domain name up-to-date.
Setting up your control panel can take a ton of time, so make sure to factor that as a cost into your revenue projections.

Consumers purchasing IBM PCs will soon get their computers pre-configured for free Internet access from Juno Online Services.
The companies today announced a multiyear distribution agreement, with IBM bundling Juno connection software with new computers at no extra charge to consumers.
PC owners can either log on directly with the Internet software, along with installation assistance for Juno clients, or by taking the file with a new Internet connection plugin installed in the computer.
The agreement is a big plus for the Internet service provider, making the transition for the one-time connected more affordable than ever.
"The offer of free use of the Juno Internet Access software with IBM notebook and desktop personal computers is a powerful tool for the one-time Internet connection," said Jonathan Chapman, Juno senior vice president. "We are thrilled to be the first global Internet Service Provider in the world to offer free Internet connection to the computer purchasers worldwide. (CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells have up to 100 times more telomere length — the DNA microstructure that occurs at the ends of a human chromosome — than human ones. This means the average human has fewer telomeres (the ends of chromosomes are like a clock that gives a cell a certain amount of time to divide) than rabbits, dogs and other animals.
UCLA scientists have figured out how the animal repairs broken pieces of its chromosome. Once the pieces are broken, elephant fibroblast cells make copies of their own chromosomes so they can go through the cell cycle more quickly. Elephants can also offer up these chromosomes through the connection with other cells in the body.

The earliest chart in the data series comes from 1553, when Sir Hugh Willoughby and Richard Chancellor, commanders of two expeditions sent out by the Company of Merchant Adventurers, recorded their observations of the ice edge. Early charts are irregularly spaced and the curvature of the earth means that the edge shows as a step function across maps of the area. This induced step function had to be treated when constructing barycentric maps of the area from Mahalanobis distance normals.

Composting is the ultimate win-win-win for gardeners.
It is recycling at its most basic, turning yard and kitchen waste into rich, organic planting material. It saves money on fertilizer and chemical herbicides, reduces air and water pollution, and provides a cooling effect on a hot summer day.
Adding compost to the soil helps make the root zone more fibrous so the plants can get more water and nutrients.
Compost can also help control soil moisture and our most important microorganisms, bacteria and fungi, which keep the soil loose and well aerated !
Grass clippings are one of the best feed sources for your garden. We don't add grass clippings to the composting process except from the cool season gardens when the plants are large enough to handle the nitrogen feeding the clippings supply.
Hot rototill new gardens are a no no! Spades are much safer.
If you are a lawn gardener you can compost your grass clippings!

Stanley Karnow, the award-winning author and journalist who wrote a definitive book about the Vietnam War, worked on an accompanying documentary and later won a Pulitzer for a history of the Philippines, died Sunday morning. He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C., according to a family friend.
Karnow's acclaimed books — Vietnam: A History (1983) and In Our Image (1989) — examined the 100-year history of U.S. foreign policy in the Southeast Asian country with and the American-owned colony of the Philippines.
His books were acclaimed for their scope and detail, a fact embraced by the late U.S. Gen. William Yorshuck and the Associated Press.
His books became frequent textbook references for college courses on Southeast Asian history and the origins of the Vietnam War.

Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help you plan an assignment, subsequent tasks the project will require and a timeline for the entire project.
This helpful business tool enables you to analyze a task by varying the assumptions involved with the project. Essentially, the decision tree lets you sample possible upsides and downfalls with a project, just as you can with a business plan. When you have a decision tree with you during important discussions with a client or other major decision-maker, you can detail exactly what is required to meet each approaach you suggest, so a decision-maker can visualize the various possible results to choose the best possible project plan.
To create a decision tree diagram easily, turn it into a spreadsheet with your criteria: the steps you plan to take with the project, the possible outcomes the project may have, the time required for each of the steps, steps that are more rather than less effective with the project – and other criteria you may have with your project so far.

The town will now consider changing its animal ordinance.
A Berlin woman is trying to keep her pet goat despite a town ordinance.
A dwarf goat named Benny has been living in a backyard pen at 3 Chestnut Street with her pet owner Theresa Brown since 2007.
She had applied to keep the goat shortly after she bought it with the intention of displaying it with a pet turtle she also owns during the Christmas season.
She successfully obtained a permit after the town’s gatekeepers on the issue the parks committee, approved the idea, according to The Associated Press.
The ordinance bans farm animals except horses so Brown started a petition and organized a meeting of pet owners to challenge the law.
She claims that cows and horses are more prone to cause neighborhood accidents compared with tiny goats like hers.
Neighbors also don’t have a problem with Benny Brown.
However, the issue arises during the time when the Task force issues recommendations proposing a modification in the town code to prohibit large farm animals in suburban neighborhoods.

Adele has broken down in tears on stage as she dedicated the latest leg of her worldwide tour to victims of the Orlando shooting.
A seven-year-old Adele fan had his dream of meeting her come true after she noticed the child couldn’t get a view of the star because of security barriers.
His grandmother contacted the singer, explaining the boy had a rare condition that made him ‘fall backwards’, leaving him particularly vulnerable to security precautions.
Several small monitors had been installed so that kids sat near the platform – but the barrier was blocking one of the monitors so the grandmother asked the boy to watch the show from the side of the stage next to the monitors.
Asked after the show how the little one felt about the experience, she said her grandson had been ‘awe’struck’ by meeting Adele, telling the BBC:
“She came over to him before the show and asked how old he was – I said ‘7.’
“‘Are you going to sing ‘Rolling In the Deep?’ she said ‘Are you going to smile?’

Pat Maloney was a gifted experimental musician in the 1970s, until he suddenly stopped playing entirely.
This story starts with an ending.

Following the Fall is a bizarre tale of the relationships and mysteries that comprised the final decade in the life of a musician: a late-chapter detective case more infamous—and acclaimed—for its forgotten history than its final denouement.

Q. I have an annuity worth about $70,000. I am retired and I need the money. They say I would get $125 a month for 10 years. This isn't enough. Can you recommend a plan that gives more? — Beverly
A. Annual income may have decreased more than your annuity benefit. This usually occurs when the average return earned on your fixed investments such as certificates of deposit isn't enough to keep up with inflation and keep purchasing power where you want it.
Thus, your $125 a month isn't going to make the grade until you figure interest rates have changed much more favorable and you gain more months of deferral time.
If you!re nervous about market downturns during that time (which you shouldn't be, since you can take withdrawals during the deferral time if you don't desire a full annuity payment), you might await a market improvement and choose a deferred immediate annuity (DIA).
A DIA provides periodic payments (as stated in your annuity surrender schedule)

A Canton-based food pantry that feeds hundreds of families across western Wayne County is getting a boost as it heads toward the Thanksgiving holiday.
Open Door Ministry, which feeds about 430 struggling families, has a chest freezer donated to the group just in time for the holidays. Volunteers with the group have already started feeding more people.
“This is the season of helping people,” Organizing Committee President Matt Schmeling said.
On May 4 – the group’s national holiday – the organization needed donated vehicles to pick up food to feed the clients. Thirty groups have worked with the group the last three years,
“We had a bunch of donated vehicles that needed some maintenance work and since the local (Wayne County Habitat For Humanity affiliate had a grant to clean the garbage out the donated vehicles, they donated those to the organization (for the people receiving the help),” Schmeling said.
Before the late donation, the group had one freezer used to store the bulk food purchases made by clients for the senior group baskets going into the holiday season.

A new study by researchers at The Kinsey Institute and the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center has found that the timeless, multicultural tradition of grandmothering might have an unexpected benefit: helping some women temper their hot flamin’ temper.
Those women tend to have a greater range of ability and opportunity to soothe themselves after an argument with a loved one (which, let’s face it, most of us experience with loved ones on a near-daily basis), according to the study published this week in the journal Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, following a study published last year looking at these effects for daughters.
Grandmothers have an easier time calming down than daughters after an argument with a loved one
Megan Gill and her colleagues recruited a group of mostly older women with grandchildren – so just grandmothers – to participate in the study.
The researchers had the groups keep a brief diary over the course of a day, detailing any arguing that went on during the day, the resolution (or lack thereof) of that argument, and how rapidly they calmed themselves after the conversation was over.

Analysis: OpenMFG helps fill the void of open-source ERP applications for small and midsized businesses.
For the largest enterprises, access to the source code of their enterprise resource planning applications is a given -- just one more task required with managing a large IT project.
But the small-to-midsize business world (SMBs) typically aren't afforded the same kind of involvement with the applications behind the scenes.
Yet the affordability of SMB applications is another reason suggested by the mainframe industry for increasing SMB adoption. For example, the SAP Small Business Suite (SBS), which debuts with the SAP My SAP Access version to SAP customers in late March, will have the Y2K fix completely baked into the SBS license -- a tremendous boon to a community that is looking for some relief in Y2K compliance.

Former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, musician Bob Dylan and astronaut John Glenn were among a select group of 13 Americans named by President Obama Thursday as the latest recipients of the nation’s highest civilian honor, the Presidential Medal of Freedom.
Albright, the first female secretary of state and the first woman to join the ranks of the presidentially appointed Cabinet officials since the presidency of Franklin D. Roosevelt, also became the second-ever recipient of the award in the category of national security (yes, President Reagan won one too — in 1977).
“The Glories of Hallowed Battle Committee (GHBC) is so proud to acknowledge Mrs. Madeleine K. Albright’s achievements, particularly in the realm of national security. The GHBC embraces all individuals with the GHSBB I Want My Freedom ribbon which symbolizes a cause worthy to continue the fight towards completing the most precious gift of all – freedom and equal opportunity for all men and women,” said Deanna Brown, commander of this organization.

The hour-long debate will be shown on BBC2 from 7pm on November 26th.
The parties announced the agreement earlier today, with the broadcaster saying the "October revolution" gives the general public a chance to see directly how the parties differ.

Randy Johnson could be in pinstripes by this time next week.
Despite a stumbling block yesterday and a few hurdles that still need to be cleared, an industry source said last night the complicated multi-team trade for the New York Yankees' costly free agent closer appears to be close to completion.
Johnson's agent, Rex Barney, confirmed no deal had yet been done despite earlier reports the Yankees traded second baseman Alfonso Soriano and $67 million from the Chicago Cubs - a reported $700,000 more than the Seattle Mariners had reportedly offered the Cubs - to get Johnson.
Johnson spoke with Barney yesterday and the Yankees have spent some time talking to the soft-spoken, 42-year-old closer recently, Barney confirmed.
If a deal occurs, Barney believes the sides should formalize the agreement this morning.
Asked whether a final agreement between the Cubs and the Yankees remains a possibility, Barney responded, ""We are going to talk with the Cubs more over the next couple of days."

NEW YORK (MarketWatch) — Treasury prices extended their pullback Tuesday, propelling the government debt market to its fourth day of losses in five sessions, after data showed service-sector companies expanded at a quickened pace during the month of March.
A gain in equities, with financial services a leading sector after Federal Reserve Vice Chair Janet Yellen gave a speech with an ultra-dovish bent that also poured more cold water on the idea of a Fed rate hike in the near-to-medium term, also worked against the bond market.
“With the outcome of the (Fed) meeting so close, no one could sustain a large-scale buying [long] position on bonds,” wrote Sean Campbell, director Macro Research at S&P Capital IQ, in commentary e-mailed to MarketWatch.

The Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 was enacted to protect employees who need to take absences from work to care for themselves or their family members due to medical problems. This law was amended in 2008 with the purpose to allow men to take time off from work to care for a seriously ill parent-in-law.
NYDOH-COMI Implementation: Leave of Absence
Workers' compensation law prohibits discrimination against injured workers who take time off jobs due to work-related injuries or claims under the general workers' compensation law (or occupational accident law). Workers under the self-insured workers' compensation law are also prohibited from receiving adverse action for taking time off to receive treatment without pay after a work-related injury until the date that the final determination on the compensability of the workers' compensation claim is made by the workers' compensation board or the Workers' Compensation Law judge determines the workers' compensation claim to be abated.

MEXICO CITY (AP) — A man was arrested Monday in the shooting death of a journalist who worked for the newspaper El Heraldo de Chiapas, and authorities were searching for three other people suspected of having ordered the assassination. The killing Saturday of Gregorio Jiménez de la Cruz increased already high fears about the safety of journalists in the western Mexican state of Chiapas.
Security video footage showed large crowds marching in the southern city of Tuxtla Gutierrez for the deceased journalist. Jiménez de la Cruz had frequently reported on the absence of security in the city after a sidering earthquake in September.
Jiménez de la Cruz wrote about the grinding poverty of the coastal flatlands of Chiapas a state of some 1.4 million people that lies next to the southern border with Guatemala.
Hundreds also attended a candlelight vigil in the name of Jiménez de la Cruz near the offices of El Heraldo de Chiapas where a chapel filled with flaming candles remained lit all night.

On October 30, a major new report on the impact of Marcellus Shale gas development on water resources will be issued. Water Resource Reporting and Water Footprint from Marcellus Shale Development in West Virginia and Pennsylvania, authored by the USGS and the Ohio River Valley Institute, provides a summary of drinking water salinization and related impacts and a sobering perspective on the hydraulic fracturing boom in the Marcellus Shale:
This report summarizes our findings from the study of a number of published and peer-reviewed studies revealing the following: 1) Marcellus Shale (and associated hydraulic fracturing) may devolatilize (partially release the trapped gas into the well bore and fractures) large volumes fractured wells create a material volume of liquid effluent (~ 60-barrel) stream that may result in a treatment capacity of thousands of barrels. Both processes are discussed in the literature – but currently are largely a black box in that no one other than the operator and the service companies has a reliable idea of what volume is produced. How do I know when I should exit a trade?
Are there some rules on this that I can follow?
Many traders approach their strategy with one thing in mind: establishing the qualifications for entry. The ‘edge’ if you will in their rules. This allows these traders, the entry trigger conditions.
Here are some conditions that can trigger your entry into a position.
Entry will trigger with benign support (a swing of the Bowl Type 1 pivot scale).
Entry will trigger with Bank of America (BOA) origins a time in the cash market session.
Entry will trigger with enhanced volume enhancers (time frame after the turn or after a time bin range entry trigger (for example the ‘official close’ hour, the time frame after the turn hour, or upon a time bin entry trigger time frame).
Entry trigger conditions are all important. But some conditions are more important that others. We need a reasonable trigger conditions so that we know with 70 percent certainty that a trade entry criteria can make a profit (not happen, make a profit!).

ZURICH, April 10 (Reuters) - Sunrise Communications' top shareholder on Wednesday blocked plans to extend the company's right to issue fresh capital to 2021, complicating a boardroom struggle for control.
A group led by billionaire entrepreneur Marcus Jooste made the move, according to a filing with Switzerland's securities watchdog FINMA on Thursday.
The group controls a voting stake worth more than 20 percent in the former Mannesmann broadband telecoms business.
A similar move last month from the group had a similar impact then, triggering a call for a new board meeting.
The 4-2 board vote a week ago broke a power struggle triggered by denial-of-service (DDoS) cyber attacks on the telecoms group after it published a major tax issue with the Netherlands last month , allowing the Jooste group to seize control with a cash injection in the boardroom row.

In the same time span, global asset allocation — during which investors allocate capital on a net basis across the board — had inflows of $103 billion (Rs5,004 crore today). However, one can look at the India segment and see a markedly lower treatment metrics — just $500 million (Rs250 crore today) in net capital inflows compared to $800 million (Rs420 crore today) seen in global asset allocation funds.
Investors over the last three months have reduced the allocation to India. According to Citigroup Research, the so-called India allocation angle has reduced to 0.19 per cent mandate-wide from 0.60 per cent three months ago, with returns from the index underperforming global indices by a wide margin.

Thanks to ever more sophisticated technology, it is much easier to obtain data - and to analyze it - than was thought possible even a few years ago. As a result, there is an understandable feeling that decision-making in organizations can no longer be handled with the methodologies to which people have grown accustomed over the years. Our experience with decision analysis (DA) confirms this impression, with some interesting interpretations and some refinements.
As a framework for accepting, developing and evaluating ideas, the framework designed 300 years ago (the one embracing a three-legged stool [for decision making]) was very successful (see Figure I: The three legs, viewed across time). Our experience confirms that the decision-making framework (which breaks issues into three logical areas) was a finely-developed comparison tool. The three logical areas are (1) the decision analysis (DA) decision maker (DM), (2) the decision maker (DM) group, (including the parties responsible for implementing suggestions), and (3) the decision maker area (DA), which monitors the effects after the decision.

How many gubernatorial elections will Pennsylvania hold this November? A trick question? Yes, sort of – but the question reveals an issue that impacts the recall election of Gov. Scott Walker (R) (see the May issue of Berkshire magazine for the explanation).
In short, the reason the WI recall feels so consequential is that the return of the recall law means it can return in other states – particularly the Midwest. Recalls are already underway in WI (against Gov. Walker) and least one other (more below).
As for Pennsylvania, the commonwealth already had its own recall law (see the May issue again for more detail), plus the unique fact that a statewide recall election can take place during a special election to determine a vacancy.
Now, technically the GOP primary – involving all sorts of other factors – determines the governor for the final three months of the year, but the recall law means those three months might not make a difference.
Not yet anyway.

There is no easy option for Northern Ireland after Brexit.
Deciding on post-Brexit border arrangements between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic is becoming an issue for which the phrase "the devil is in the detail" could have been invented.
On a number of occasions US President Donald Trump has expressed strong views about the need for a physical line on the island of Ireland (which would require the return of a corridor between north and south Antrim).
His latest concern, published in the Irish Daily Star newspaper, is causing great anxiety for the officials tasked with deciding how all the necessary issues are going to be resolved after March 2019.
Amid all the headlines about the so-called "hard" or "soft" borders after the completion of the withdrawal agreement by the UK and the EU, a newer version of a name that never captured the interest of the general public during the earlier stages of the discussions – a "regulatory border" – is gaining a foothold in the see-and-believe world of news from Brussels.
But a regulatory border is not a newly-invented concept;

Hackers extracted lists of files from computers that they contaminated with the virus that triggered cyberattacks last week in the United States and South Korea, police in Seoul said Tuesday.
The attacks, in which flooding the victims with constant screen alerts with bold messages demanding payment to kill the alerts or with fake antivirus messages, affected tens of thousands of people in the two countries.
Investigators looking into the so-called WannaCry attack also have discovered at least some of the techniques hackers used to gain entry into the computers — a strong indication the perpetrators had inside information, according to Seoul’s Yongsan Police Department.
Those techniques are similar to the sometimes default settings available when a computer operating system’s administrative access credentials aren’t required, the police said.
Investigators have also discovered the domain registering the WannaCry domain address — a common first step for hackers looking to take traffic so the malware they’re spreading can hide behind the domain or use the domain ‘traffic to infected machines. Seoul police are currently reviewing other domain records to determine potential perpetrators

In Sudan, the head of the newly installed military council resigned Friday, just one day after he was sworn in following the ouster of Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir, after thousands gathered in the capital Khartoum, calling on him to resign.
A group of army officers had arrested and deposed Bashir Thursday, after more than three months of demonstrations calling for the president to step down. Bashir led Sudan for three decades. Its military leadership charged the deposed president with possessing millions of dollars in cash in the United Arab Emirates, but also with corruption to the tune of more than $90 million.
Amid the ongoing protests, the deposed military leadership reportedly deployed soldiers across Sudan to crush the demonstrations. Thousands have reportedly fled. There have also been multiple reports of soldiers injuring and arresting people across the country the past couple days.

MYRTLE BEACH, SC (WMBF) - As our world continues to advance with the help of technology, artificial intelligence (AI) has generated a lot of buzz lately in healthcare. AI healthcare providers are already saving lives and making appointments easier – so why can't it also be applied during pregnancy?
In a world-first published Thursday in the science journal PLOS ONE, Johns Hopkins Medicine researchers applied a deep learning algorithm called DeepGestalt to a Baylor College of Medicine dataset made of obstetrics records, resulting in the creation of an obstetrics clinical decision support tool that enables providers to identify maternal preeclampsia – a dangerous condition marked by elevated blood pressure during pregnancy – with near-perfect accuracy.
Click the image above to watch a demonstration of DeepGestalt in action

Plans are gathering pace for Bradford’s new City Library with the arrival of a new temporary children’s library in City Park today.

Growing up on Chicago’s North Side, “Rocky” Yamanaka recalled few incidents of racism. “Me and my sister were the only Japanese. But we were curiosities to most of the Caucasian kids,” reminiscing the words of his Browning High School classmates. As a native Chicagoan (60 years of age), the topic of racism is one rarely discussed—though common during the infancy stages of Yamanaka’s youth (established in the ‘50s).
Yamanaka’s days as a schoolchild weren’t ideal. The imprisonment of Japanese-Americans during World War II was fresh on the minds of people, so Yamanaka had many a discussion with people on the topic.
With the draft during the Vietnam War on the horizon, most people (almost all schoolmates anyway) swept the idea of extremism under the rug, avoiding big topics such as racism. Nevertheless, Yamanaka did see the all-to-common incidences of schoolmates logging onto the brownskinned athletes collectively.
